bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, September 19, 1941

div1.p: Hench is pleased that the material he sent to Wood will be helpful. He comments on how to treat the Moran-Kissinger controversy regarding who volunteered first. Truby believes that Agramonte has written an article with errors, but Hench is not certain who is correct.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, September 19, 1941
div1.opener:
September 19, 1941
Miss Laura Wood
1338 Nineteenth St. N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Miss Wood:
div1.p:
I am glad that you expect my material to be helpful and I am indeed
sorry that my conscience would not permit me to send you Major Reed's letters.
I sincerely hope that you can still see them, not only the ones pertaining to
1900 - 1901, but his earlier letters. I wrote to General Reed asking for further
permission from him or as an alternative asking him if I could send to his sister
a letter, a carbon copy of which I sent to him. I have not heard from him and
suspect that he doesn't even want me to write to her. Just why they are protecting
her so assiduously, I don't know.

I saw General Truby's original manuscript but it has been revised ex-
tensively and I understand I am to see the revised copy shortly. What I saw
was most interesting. We had quite a lively discussion about the location and
identification of the buildings at Camp Columbia until I was lucky enough to
find an old map which settled the matter. I imagine it was a copy of this map
which he showed you. I have had extensive visits and correspondence with Moran
and Kissinger and as you did, I found a discrepancy in their story. Both of
these men are entirely honest, I am sure, but it is merely a matter of memory,
and I don't think we can even trust General Truby as to who was first. Certainly
Moran would know better than Truby. I believe that the best solution to the
problem is to do what all other writers have done--to avoid this controversy
and to lump the two men together as having volunteered together. After three
years I have been unable to get the men to agree, even though I got them both
in a hotel room at Washington and Jefferson last year.

Miss Blossom's Reed's letters I believe would give you many details
about Reed's earlier residences. I have the book “Old Jules”. As you say,
it is not particularly important but it was mildly interesting.

Let me repeat my offer to go over your manuscript. I shall be very
glad to do it and indeed very interested to do it. Let me warn you that General
Truby believes that Agramonte's article in the Popular Science Monthy has many
errors in it. Who was right, Agramonte or Truby, I cannot entirely judge.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
Miss Laura Wood
- 2 -
September 19, 1941
P. S. Let me give you the results of my efforts to determine just who
were present when Moran was first subjected to the experiments in Bldg. 2. Do you
have Senate Document 822, the official compilation of the yellow fever work? On
pages 10, 86 and 100 of this document it mentions two controls only being on Side A
(the mosquito-free side). These two controls were apparently non-immune volunteers
but they have never been identified. Moran doesn't recall who they were. On page
100 Reed says that the two controls continued to sleep in that room at night. On
page 99 Reed mentions two controls and one other non-immune who were on the opposite
side of the screen from Moran. Apparently this “other non-immune” was Reed himself.
Apparently he merely entered the mosquito-free side of the room briefly for the pur-
pose of seeing Moran bitten. This data I found in Agramonte's scientific Monthly
article Dec. 1915, on page 235 (bottom) where it says, “During this time two other
men and Major Reed remained in the other compartment, separated from Moran....etc.”
(This is why Miss Hallock had three figures drawn in the left box of the diagram
on p. 21 of the enclosed Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's pamphlet. But the
events pictured in Figures 1 and 3 on p. 21 never occurred, despite Gorgas' garbled
version given on p. 243 of the Senate Document).
But in Miss Reed's manuscript I found still another version of the incident.
In the letter written by Reed to his family supposedly dated Dec. 26, 1900 Reed
describes Moran's experiment and says, “I stood with Dr. Carroll and Dr. Ames on
the other side (of the screen) at the place marked “B” and saw the insect light...etc.
Bed marked “B” is being occupied by a non-immune who sleeps within one foot of the
screen, breathing the same air as in room with bed “A” (infected room). This young
non-immune is quite well, but the young fellow (i.e. Moran) who went in on the 21st
was suddenly stricken today at noon (just four days after he entered and was bitten)
with a sharp attack of what promises to be yellow fever....etc.”
Obviously there is an error. The supposed date of this letter is Dec. 26
but I imagine the date has been misread and was really Dec. 25. Reed would hardly have
made a mistake in dating a letter on Christmas Day and yet the letter must have been
written then because (1) he speaks of Dec. 21 and then this noon, four days later..etc.
(2) also a glance at the official record of Moran's case with his fever chart, etc.
shows that Moran took sick (really) on Christmas Day, had a fever of 104 that after-
noon but did not have a fever that high on the 26th.
One must conclude that there may have been, not two but perhaps five persons
in the mosquito-free side of Bldg. #2 when Moran was being bitten on the other side.
These were Drs. Reed, Carroll, Ames and at least one and probably two non-immune
volunteers. Why Reed should only mention one (“this young non-immune”) in the letter
to his family where everywhere else it speaks of two non-immune volunteers I do not
know. It's just one more of the scores and scores of contradictions I've already
found in the various official and unofficial records of the experiments. One is almost
tempted to complain that although the results of the experiments were clear as crystal
and the experiments themselves meticulously done, the records regarding incidental
details were rather sloppily kept (or poorly remembered later).
P.S. Hench, M.D.
